Roxana Margarita López Martínez

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/9071222999086778
  • Última atualização do currículo em 26/09/2018

Possui graduação em Licenciatura en Biología - Universidad de El Salvador (2015). Tem experiência na área de manejo e conservação dos recursos naturais e gestão da vida selvagem. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2018 - Atual
Molecular Defense Mechanisms in South American Fish Could Reveal Adaptation to Pollution
Descrição: In the previous IFS project, that was carried out between 2013-2017, we were able to: 1) Identify sites in the Rio Grande city (RS, Brazil) with distinct levels of contaminants (i.e. PAHs; Chivittz et al., 2016), 2) Identify the CYP1A mRNA sequence in three South American guppies inhabiting those sites, and 3) validate the use of RT-qPCR to evaluate the levels of the environmental biomarker CYP1A (Pinto et al. 2015; Ferreira et al. 2016; Chivittz et al., 2016). In the present renewal project our main goal will be to investigate molecular mechanisms involved in the adaptation of fish populations that live in the polluted sites in respect to the pristine sites. Guppies will be sampled in nine sites of Rio Grande city, three with high level of pollution (i.e. wastewater effluents, oil refinery and industrial complex), three with intermediate levels of pollution and three reference sites, in order to investigate: 1) The genetic diversity and the possible bottleneck effect in those nine fish populations using a low cost method, the Random Amplified Polimorphic DNA (RAPD); 2) The existence of the CYP1A refractory phenotype using RT-qPCR. The CYP1A refractory phenotype has been investigated in fish populations of North America, as a useful marker for fish adaptation to pollution (e.g. Bello et al., 2001). To achieve that, guppies from the nine populations will be exposed in laboratory to the CYP1A inducers BNF (betanaphtoflavone; non-carcinogenic) and B[a]P (benzo[a]pyrene; carcinogenic); and 3) evaluate the phase-II biotransformation enzyme glutathione S-transferase (GST) in order to investigate the role of GSTs in the adaptation to pollution in the guppies. We expect that the investigation of adaptation mechanisms in South American guppies could be an important contribution to the basic understanding of adaptation and toxic effects caused by environmental contaminants..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Mestrado acadêmico: (3) .

Integrantes: Roxana Margarita López Martínez - Integrante / Juliano Zanette - Coordenador / BRUNO ROSWAG MACHADO - Integrante / Camila Soares Borges - Integrante / Ralf Kersanach - Integrante / Christian Nolorbe Payahua - Integrante / Luiz Roesch - Integrante.
Financiador(es): International Foundation for Science - Auxílio financeiro.
